title: Towards Hierarchical Rectified Flow
author: Yichi Zhang (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Yici Yan (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Alex Schwing (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Zhizhen Zhao (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), ...
relevance_why: The hierarchical nature of the proposed model could be applied to improve generative modeling techniques in audio, particularly in synthesizing complex audio signals from simpler distributions.
background: Hierarchical rectified flow aims to model multimodal data distributions through a series of ordinary differential equations, enabling more efficient sampling from complex distributions.
contribution: This paper introduces a hierarchical rectified flow to solve the problem of modeling multimodal distributions, achieving straight integration paths during data generation.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods such as classic rectified flow capture only the expected velocity, leading to unnecessarily curved paths.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work models the full velocity distribution and allows for intersecting paths, leading to less curvy integration trajectories and fewer neural function evaluations.

key_innovation: The method allows for modeling velocity distributions in a hierarchical manner, enabling more accurate generation of data samples compared to existing approaches that only estimate expected velocities.
real_world_impact: This approach could significantly enhance the efficiency and quality of generative models used in various applications, including audio and image synthesis, while minimizing computational costs.
limitations: The authors mention reliance on the Euler method for sampling, indicating potential room for improvement in numerical methods.

new_terms.hierarchical rectified flow: **Hierarchical rectified flow** is a generative model that uses multiple linked ordinary differential equations to capture complex data distributions more effectively than traditional methods.
